attributes.comment:
My comment is about the potential adjustment of the fees of filings for petition to
adopt an orphan. You need to understand how expense this process already is
for families that want to adopt these children and give them the loving and
supportive home environment that they need in order to flourish as they grow. The
first thing someone needs to put their finger on is that families are not only paying
these fees once, but most often TWICE. The expiration on the petitions,
approvals, and finger prints do not coinside with each other or with the lengthy
waiting times for most international adoptions.
No matter what type of fee is involved, a 66% rate increase is just ludicrous! I
believe that relates to Price Gouging. Can you imiagine if the cost of a gallon of
milk went up 66% next week? Or the price of gas. What if the oil companies
raised it from $2.60 a gallon this week to 4.32 next week, what would be the
reaction across the nation? And I bet the government would get involved. But
now it they are trying the same thing. Maybe because it affects what seems to
be a small group of US citizens that you can just sneak this one by. But what
you are doing is once again dividing the people in to upper class and middle
class. You are raising the financial bar of who can "afford" to have children. Does
the USCIS really want to be responsible for forcing a family to make a decision of
whether or not they can afford the fees in order to have a child? In order to have a
family? If I was pregnant and on welfare the government would subsidize my
hospital bills. But since I am middle class and unable to have biological children,
the government wants it to cost me even more to bring my daughter home.
Yeah, that really gives me the warm and fuzzy feeling about We The People, For
the People.
NOT!
OK, realistically. If you feel it necessary for such a large increase in fees, extend
the expiration of all the documents and fingerprintings out to 18 or 24 months so
families are required to only pay the fees once.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Melissa Combs
